Hazlett, will present the speakers.
It is expected that Reuben Pasarew will talk on football, Pete
Swindell on lacrosse, George Margolis on basketball, Leonard Emmert on track, and Hazlett on
swimming, besides representatives
of several other sports.

II. NO SPIES
Early in June I sailed from New
York City. I then slept five days of
exotic dreams before the first sight
of land, which happened to be a little
rock off the coast of Porto Rica—
once mistaken for a full-rigged mano-war and fired upon.
For three
more days we passed isle after isle
—but none quite the right one. Each
was terrible at sea level with wrinkles of rock. Each island town was
a colony of red-brick mushrooms as
against the thick yellow-green foliage of the hills. Each isle was set
in the Caribbean like a hanging garden—between sky and sea—between
the upper heavens above for the Pure
Spirits and the richer purple-streaked
Hell below of the vile water of Pluto. Noble—but not yet!

A week already. Behind were the
Little paradise drops—the islands: St.
Thomas, St. Kitts, Antigua, Guadaloupe—none, the Bali I was searching for. At last as we headed toward
Fort de France, capital of French
Martinique, along its coast, I saw a
strand of beach—of listless palms
and primitive huts in the foreground,
and a possible jungle in the rear. Immediately I knew that the great local

them.

So much I had gleaned from the
isles en route. But I was undaunted.
I stood firm in a little room in the
white, cold gouvernment.
Little
knots of of native police in brown
uniforms hovered in the corners. In
front of me was a large desk at
whose wings sat two dusky little
secretaries—so similar as to be twins.
I marveled at their symmetry, until
I realized that I was facing a stout,
fierce bluster of a man—surely the
governor—jutting out dangerously
from between his menials.
"Bonjour, monsieur," I started,
realizing that this was the beginning
of a long hard, linguistic journey.
"Bonjour," he blustered back.
"Je sis American. Pas de brigand.
No pirate. Je desire rester ici for
about a month. I want to study this
Land of Escape—this tropical paradise .. . " It went all very well until
I came to explain that I had no passport, no visa, nothing. I didn't remember that passport was the same
in French as in English. I began to
think of all the substitutes for the
word passport that could ever be possibly invented. International ticket,
native notice, national note—avis de
commerce, billet de pays, etc.—all
sorts of queer phrases which must
have been truly astonishing to the
unimaginative automat in front of
me.
"Sacre Bleu!" said the automat,
astonished. He had understood nothing.
I now realized that I was in a
tough spot. The blood rushed to my
cheeks. Even had I communicated
the fact that I had no passport, that
I was not a spy, and that I was
harmless, they might not let me in.

Ward Promising
Many of the new candidates have
given very promising performances.
In particular, Norbert Schmidt and
Day indicate that they are varsity
material. Bob Ward, a freshman from
Poly, will no doubt be in the starting line-up, should he maintain the
splendid showing he has made up to
the present. An able punter, Ward
also shows some ability in passing
the pigskin. He is a capable ball-carrier, running well and having the faculty of following his interference.
Popow, another newcomer, appears
to be a potential lineman, although
he has not, at yet, participated in
scrimmage because of injury.

Competition
As The Standard

The Johns Hopkins handball team
is preparing for its second year of
intercollegiate activity.
With every member of last year's
varsity team reporting, the future
seems bright.
Manager Dick Pasternak has contacted fifteen colleges and has prepared an intensive program.
All candidates for the team are
urged to report to the gym on Friday at 4 o'clock. All those interested
in handball please communicate with
Dick Pasternak, Postoffice box 781.
Since a system is being arranged
whereby the gloves and handballs
will be available at all times only,
however, to those who are interested
enough in the game to report at once.
Successful Season Foreseen
Co-captains Krell and Hernandez
hope to better last year's records of
4 wins and 1 loss against college
competition. Last year's season began with a victory over Western
Maryland on the Hopkins courts, but
was followed by a loss in a return
match on Western Maryland's fourwall courts. This was followed by
two victories over Virginia and was
climaxed by swamping our traditional rivals, St. John's.
All the members of last year's
squad have improved their game considerably through intensive practice
during the summer.
The members of the squad are Joe
Krell, Joaquin Hernandez, Ted Wiehe,
Dick Pasternak, Red Glantz, M. Kramer, Dick Byer, Rosen, and N. Finkelstein.

Shuttlecock To Fly Again
The Johns Hopkins undergraduate
badminton team will start its schedule in the latter part of October at
Montebello Junior High School. The
Hopkins gymnasium is no longer
available because of future basketball games to be held there.
However, the team, bolstered up
by new blood from the incoming
freshman class, expects to repeat last
year's excellent season during which
the team won four out of six matches,
thus placing well up among the leaders of the Baltimore Badminton
League.

Offs To End Season
The first round of inter-frat touch
football starts today with Phi Kappa
Psi vs. Tau Alpha Phi. Last year's
touch football inovation was a great
success, and it is expected that this
year there will be even more enthusiasm and spirit shown in the fraternity competition.
The fraternities are divided into
four divisions, the winner of each to
meet in semi-finals and utlimately
finals to determine the champions.
Regular Weekly Competition
Each fraternity is to play at least
one game a week, all postponed
games played off on Monday afternoons and on Tuesday and Wednesday of the week beginning Monday,
October 18.
Playoffs for the championship will
take place on November 21, 22, and
26. The winners will be awarded a
bronze plaque.
Schedule For This Week
Tuesday, Oct. 8—Phi Kappa Psi
vs. Tau Alpha Phi, Field No. 1; Kappa Sigma vs. Sigma Phi Epsilon,
Field No. 2.
Wednesday, Oc. 9—Delta Upsilon
vs. Phi Gamma Delta, Field No. 1;
Pi Lambda Phi vs. Tau Alpha Omega, Field No. 2.
Thursday, Oct. 10—Kappa Alpha
vs. Delta Phi, Field No. 1; Beta Theta Pi vs. Omicron Kappa Omicron,
Field No. 2.
Friday, Oct. 11—Phi Sigma Delta
vs. Alpha Delta, Field No. 1; Alpha
Tau Omega vs. Phi Alpha, Field No.
2.

THE RISE of Joe Louis to preeminence in the boxing game has, in
addition to driving sports writers to
the dictionary in frantic search for
new alliterative titles, recalled to
many the deeds of the great fighters
of his race. Louis is in the best tradition of a line that runs all the way
down from Tom Devereaux, who wazAmerican champion in 1810, to tn,
elusive Kid Chocolate, last of th t
great dusky warriors. He has, it ap
pears, all the skill of Peter Jackson
and Joe Gans, coupled with the power
of Sam Langford and Joe Wolcott.
However, Jack Johnson, now a portly
Harlem gin salesman and once holder of the crown universally conceded
to Louis, still keeps hi.§ place in the
sun. It is all of twenty years since
Lil' Ahthah, still wearing the famous
"golden smile", eased his great length
to the canvas in response to a wild
push of Jess Willard's, and, with one
huge arm upraised to keep off the
blazing Cuban sun, placidly heard
the fatal count; yet the legend of his
prowess still runs through the dark
belt. Johnson's timing is said to be
still so remarkable that he can pick
flies out cif the air. Unlike Joe Louis,
however, he blazed no meteoric trail
to the top. In fact, during the early
part of his career, Johnson lost three
fights in one week.
ALTHOUGH the obsequies may be
a trifle premature, it appears at this
writing as though the Chicago Cubs
are going to be the first of nineteen
hundred and thirty-five's "destiny
riders" to fail in achieving the ultimate triumphs. In a year which produced Sam Parks, Wilmer Allison,
and Jimmy Braddock, the men of
Grimm seem unable to overcome the
twin bugaboos of bad luck and form.
A Cub victory would be a fitting climax to a topsy-turvy year, as well as
warming the hearts of sports fans,
who are romantics to the care. Whatever the result, the Chicagoans have
proved themselves worthy of the
"miracle team" title, both in point
of perforthance and courage. Galan
and Demaree, two of the year's prize
rookies, have been particular shining
lights.

The object of the meeting is to

supervision over all interfraternity
athletic competition. These activities
will include touch football, box lacrosse, volleyball, basketball, and

Leagues To Be Formed For
Interclass Activity; Begin
Practice Next Week
Dr. Wilson Shaffer, Director of
Athletics, has announced that fall lacrosse activity will begin in the near
future.
The activity will be conducted in
such a manner that it will serve a
double purpose. Firstly, leagues will
be formed to act as a means of interclass activity. Secondly, it will
give Dr. Morrill and his assistants
an opportunity to survey the players
and obtain an accurate determination
of the type of players who will be
available for spring drill.
Call For Men Next Week
The official fall call for lacrossemen will not be made until October
14. However, contestants may practice at any time in the lower field.
The sophomores will be divided into a number of teams participating in
the sophomore league which will play
one day a week. Several freshman
teams will also be organized into a
weekly league. Days on which no
games are scheduled will be set aside
for general practice.
Winners To Meet
The winners of the freshman and
sophomore leagues will then be placed
together with

picked teams composed of juniors and seniors to determine the class championship.
There will be fivd men to a team
and the regular lacrosse rules will
govern, except that there will be no
goalie or offside ruling.
The activity will be personally supervised by Dr. Morrill, assisted by
Roland Levy and Frank Dotterweich.

Joshua Levering, twin brother

Mr. Levering was well-known as
the candidate for President of the
United States on the Prohibition

Maryland and State Comptroller.
He and his twin brother were
born in 1845. Eugene Levering
died August 2, 1928.

To Be Selected Soon

Members of the Freshman Commission will be selected at an early
date by the Hopkins "Y" Cabinet, it
was learned today.
The group is composed of twentyfive members. The selection of the
students is determined by contacts
on the campus and at Freshman
Camp. High school records also are
considered.
Every Tuesday evening the Commission meets, and on those Tuesdays on which the Supper Club is
held, the meeting is combined with
that of the Supper Club.
The Commission, which is a campus activity, has achieved much
popularity among freshmen.

Although the term "freshman" is applied
in their first year of residence at a
men
to
university, there are many men in their third
and fourth years who are, nevertheless, freshmen. To determine how this statement can
be true, we must first interpret the meaning
of the word "freshman."
A reputable dictionary describes a "freshman" as "a college student in the first year of
the course." According to this definition, the
only determining factor is the time element.
But after having been in college for two years
and having closely observed many students
during that period we venture to disagree
with accepted definitions of "freshman."
Breaking the word into its component
parts we get, fresh man, which is about the
simplest and best definition it is possible to
make. Thus, we see that a freshman is a man
who is new to the ways and ideas of the University, and is trying to become acclimated to
them.
How can a freshman become acclimated?
This is a difficult question to answer because
its solution has to deal with mental rather
than physical factors. But the closest we can
come to it is to say that a man has not become
acclimated to the University until he has acquired the Hopkins Spirit. This inevitably
leads to the query, "What is the Hopkins
Spirit'?" And here we run into an obstacle
which we can't hurdle.
The Hopkins Spirit is something intangible. It is like some powerful force, itself

So much I had gleaned from the
isles en route. But I was undaunted.
I stood firm in a little room in the
white, cold gouvernment.
Little
knots of of native police in brown
uniforms hovered in the corners. In
front of me was a large desk at
whose wings sat two dusky little
secretaries—so similar as to be twins.
I marveled at their symmetry, until
I realized that I was facing a stout,
fierce bluster of a man—surely the
governor—jutting out dangerously
from between his menials.
"Bonjour, monsieur," I started,
realizing that this was the beginning
of a long hard, linguistic journey.
"Bonjour," he blustered back.
"Je sis American. Pas de brigand.
No pirate. Je desire rester ici for
about a month. I want to study this
Land of Escape—this tropical paradise .. . " It went all very well until
I came to explain that I had no passport, no visa, nothing. I didn't remember that passport was the same
in French as in English. I began to
think of all the substitutes for the
word passport that could ever be possibly invented. International ticket,
native notice, national note—avis de
commerce, billet de pays, etc.—all
sorts of queer phrases which must
have been truly astonishing to the
unimaginative automat in front of
me.
"Sacre Bleu!" said the automat,
astonished. He had understood nothing.
I now realized that I was in a
tough spot. The blood rushed to my
cheeks. Even had I communicated
the fact that I had no passport, that
I was not a spy, and that I was
harmless, they might not let me in.

Ward Promising
Many of the new candidates have
given very promising performances.
In particular, Norbert Schmidt and
Day indicate that they are varsity
material. Bob Ward, a freshman from
Poly, will no doubt be in the starting line-up, should he maintain the
splendid showing he has made up to
the present. An able punter, Ward
also shows some ability in passing
the pigskin. He is a capable ball-carrier, running well and having the faculty of following his interference.
Popow, another newcomer, appears
to be a potential lineman, although
he has not, at yet, participated in
scrimmage because of injury.

Competition
As The Standard

The Johns Hopkins handball team
is preparing for its second year of
intercollegiate activity.
With every member of last year's
varsity team reporting, the future
seems bright.
Manager Dick Pasternak has contacted fifteen colleges and has prepared an intensive program.
All candidates for the team are
urged to report to the gym on Friday at 4 o'clock. All those interested
in handball please communicate with
Dick Pasternak, Postoffice box 781.
Since a system is being arranged
whereby the gloves and handballs
will be available at all times only,
however, to those who are interested
enough in the game to report at once.
Successful Season Foreseen
Co-captains Krell and Hernandez
hope to better last year's records of
4 wins and 1 loss against college
competition. Last year's season began with a victory over Western
Maryland on the Hopkins courts, but
was followed by a loss in a return
match on Western Maryland's fourwall courts. This was followed by
two victories over Virginia and was
climaxed by swamping our traditional rivals, St. John's.
All the members of last year's
squad have improved their game considerably through intensive practice
during the summer.
The members of the squad are Joe
Krell, Joaquin Hernandez, Ted Wiehe,
Dick Pasternak, Red Glantz, M. Kramer, Dick Byer, Rosen, and N. Finkelstein.

Shuttlecock To Fly Again
The Johns Hopkins undergraduate
badminton team will start its schedule in the latter part of October at
Montebello Junior High School. The
Hopkins gymnasium is no longer
available because of future basketball games to be held there.
However, the team, bolstered up
by new blood from the incoming
freshman class, expects to repeat last
year's excellent season during which
the team won four out of six matches,
thus placing well up among the leaders of the Baltimore Badminton
League.

Offs To End Season
The first round of inter-frat touch
football starts today with Phi Kappa
Psi vs. Tau Alpha Phi. Last year's
touch football inovation was a great
success, and it is expected that this
year there will be even more enthusiasm and spirit shown in the fraternity competition.
The fraternities are divided into
four divisions, the winner of each to
meet in semi-finals and utlimately
finals to determine the champions.
Regular Weekly Competition
Each fraternity is to play at least
one game a week, all postponed
games played off on Monday afternoons and on Tuesday and Wednesday of the week beginning Monday,
October 18.
Playoffs for the championship will
take place on November 21, 22, and
26. The winners will be awarded a
bronze plaque.
Schedule For This Week
Tuesday, Oct. 8—Phi Kappa Psi
vs. Tau Alpha Phi, Field No. 1; Kappa Sigma vs. Sigma Phi Epsilon,
Field No. 2.
Wednesday, Oc. 9—Delta Upsilon
vs. Phi Gamma Delta, Field No. 1;
Pi Lambda Phi vs. Tau Alpha Omega, Field No. 2.
Thursday, Oct. 10—Kappa Alpha
vs. Delta Phi, Field No. 1; Beta Theta Pi vs. Omicron Kappa Omicron,
Field No. 2.
Friday, Oct. 11—Phi Sigma Delta
vs. Alpha Delta, Field No. 1; Alpha
Tau Omega vs. Phi Alpha, Field No.
2.

THE RISE of Joe Louis to preeminence in the boxing game has, in
addition to driving sports writers to
the dictionary in frantic search for
new alliterative titles, recalled to
many the deeds of the great fighters
of his race. Louis is in the best tradition of a line that runs all the way
down from Tom Devereaux, who wazAmerican champion in 1810, to tn,
elusive Kid Chocolate, last of th t
great dusky warriors. He has, it ap
pears, all the skill of Peter Jackson
and Joe Gans, coupled with the power
of Sam Langford and Joe Wolcott.
However, Jack Johnson, now a portly
Harlem gin salesman and once holder of the crown universally conceded
to Louis, still keeps hi.§ place in the
sun. It is all of twenty years since
Lil' Ahthah, still wearing the famous
"golden smile", eased his great length
to the canvas in response to a wild
push of Jess Willard's, and, with one
huge arm upraised to keep off the
blazing Cuban sun, placidly heard
the fatal count; yet the legend of his
prowess still runs through the dark
belt. Johnson's timing is said to be
still so remarkable that he can pick
flies out cif the air. Unlike Joe Louis,
however, he blazed no meteoric trail
to the top. In fact, during the early
part of his career, Johnson lost three
fights in one week.
ALTHOUGH the obsequies may be
a trifle premature, it appears at this
writing as though the Chicago Cubs
are going to be the first of nineteen
hundred and thirty-five's "destiny
riders" to fail in achieving the ultimate triumphs. In a year which produced Sam Parks, Wilmer Allison,
and Jimmy Braddock, the men of
Grimm seem unable to overcome the
twin bugaboos of bad luck and form.
A Cub victory would be a fitting climax to a topsy-turvy year, as well as
warming the hearts of sports fans,
who are romantics to the care. Whatever the result, the Chicagoans have
proved themselves worthy of the
"miracle team" title, both in point
of perforthance and courage. Galan
and Demaree, two of the year's prize
rookies, have been particular shining
lights.

Latrobe Hall.
The object of the meeting is to

supervision over all interfraternity
athletic competition. These activities
will include touch football, box lacrosse, volleyball, basketball, and

Leagues To Be Formed For
Interclass Activity; Begin
Practice Next Week
Dr. Wilson Shaffer, Director of
Athletics, has announced that fall lacrosse activity will begin in the near
future.
The activity will be conducted in
such a manner that it will serve a
double purpose. Firstly, leagues will
be formed to act as a means of interclass activity. Secondly, it will
give Dr. Morrill and his assistants
an opportunity to survey the players
and obtain an accurate determination
of the type of players who will be
available for spring drill.
Call For Men Next Week
The official fall call for lacrossemen will not be made until October
14. However, contestants may practice at any time in the lower field.
The sophomores will be divided into a number of teams participating in
the sophomore league which will play
one day a week. Several freshman
teams will also be organized into a
weekly league. Days on which no
games are scheduled will be set aside
for general practice.
Winners To Meet
The winners of the freshman and
sophomore leagues will then be placed
together with

picked teams composed of juniors and seniors to determine the class championship.
There will be fivd men to a team
and the regular lacrosse rules will
govern, except that there will be no
goalie or offside ruling.
The activity will be personally supervised by Dr. Morrill, assisted by
Roland Levy and Frank Dotterweich.

Joshua Levering, twin brother
of Eugene Levering, who donated
gifts which made possible the
building of Levering 1Hall, died
Saturday night after a month's
illness.
Mr. Levering was well-known as
the candidate for President of the
United States on the Prohibition
party ticket. He was also onetime candidate for Governor of
Maryland and State Comptroller.
He and his twin brother were
born in 1845. Eugene Levering
died August 2, 1928.

To Be Selected Soon

Members of the Freshman Commission will be selected at an early
date by the Hopkins "Y" Cabinet, it
was learned today.
The group is composed of twentyfive members. The selection of the
students is determined by contacts
on the campus and at Freshman
Camp. High school records also are
considered.
Every Tuesday evening the Commission meets, and on those Tuesdays on which the Supper Club is
held, the meeting is combined with
that of the Supper Club.
The Commission, which is a campus activity, has achieved much
popularity among freshmen.

appointment Professor Albright gave
his time to his new duties, not continuing as acting head of the American School of Oriental Research.
